Posts.Content: Dec 4, 2007 09:53AM kathyjo wrote: Here is the gyst of the "thing": Epidermal inclusion cysts rarely occur in the breast, but when they do, the consequences can be severe. Here, we report the case of a 23-year-old woman who presented with a palpable mass in the right breast. The mass had persisted for 4 years and had been causing pain for 1 month at the time of the patient's presentation. We examined the mass by means of mammography and sonography. Sonographic examination revealed a well-circumscribed solid, avascular mass suggestive of an epidermal inclusion cyst. Excision was performed at the patient's request. Histopathologic examination of the mass after excision confirmed the diagnosis of epidermal inclusion cyst and its localization within the breast parenchyma. To our knowledge, reports on epidermal inclusion cysts within the breast parenchyma are rare.

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2007 09:39AM - edited Dec 28, 2007 09:40AM by kathyjo Tait - it is normal to freak out when you find something strange.  I also had an indent on my breast and when I pressed with one finger on the indent, I felt a tiny pebble.  It was VERY small and if it wasn't for the indent, I would have missed it.  Nothing showed on mammo or ultrasound due to density but I went to a surgeon anyway and had it removed and biopsied.  I'm happy to report that it was benign - dead cells or something like that......anyway, my point is that I thought for sure I had cancer because of the indent!  Don't assume the worst - always assume it's benign until told otherwise and GET IT CHECKED OUT.  It is not in your head - it's in your breast and it doesn't belong there.  Best of luck to you! Oh, and as to the Lane Bryant wired bras - I hear you, sister!  I had awful soreness from that (I'm only a 42D) so now I buy their wireless ones and they are pretty good at holding things up! :-)

Posts.Title: 3 month follow-up results LaurenBinVA TenderIsOurMight

Posts.Content: Dec 5, 2007 03:32PM kathyjo wrote: I'm sorry you got postponed.  I don't feel qualified to respond to the medication issue but I can speak to the feelings you are having about "what's the use".  I had surgery in July to remove a cyst from my diaphragm - it was pressing on my lung.  I have difficult airways - intubation is dangerous and difficult.  I thought for SURE I was going to die during surgery.  I had just lost close to 30 lbs. on weight watchers and I just stopped doing it and ate whatever I wanted and stopped exercising.  I thought like you did - what's the use....  Well, I obviously lived through the surgery, regained ALL of the weight and am unable to get my mojo back!  So, although the odds are in your favor that this is not cancer, even if it is, you will not die tomorrow.  You will have a long and hopefully healthy life after treatment.  You want your body to be in its BEST CONDITION to put up the fight!!  So, go into training so you can fight whatever comes your way. Best of luck to you.
